posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
...but a curious idiot, I was looking through Ye Olde Forgotten Reams wiki when my eye was caught by the Forest Gnome (there are reasons, but I'm not telling). Now, it struck me that such a creature would be more likely to be a Druid than a Wizard, and being a shy type, probably a SD for HiPS. And thus a whole RP character began to form in that idiotic but imaginative area between my ears (you may well see its outpourings in the Build Request forum sometime soon).

It was around then that I remembered I'd never built a Druid before, at least not a caster one (there were a couple with a few levels just for Shifter). Thus, here I am with a couple of questions (at least to start with). But first, some givens: no Dragon Shape; there will be at least 1, but probably 2, minor class(es) involved, so no telling me to play a pure one this time; and it will be a gnome, which I appreciate isn't necessarily the best race.

So, the questions: i) while I appreciate that Conjuration is well-regarded as the prime school - mostly for Implosion and SoV, Evocation appeals as druidic for the elemental stuff, and so does Abjuration for the same reason - druidic in nature, though not so elemental. Would I be over-gimping myself by taking one of the latter two? ii) Blind Fight, is it still worth it - ditto for KD (assuming IKD is less needed when shifting into animal/elemental form)? iii) Do all creature weapons react positively to Imp Crit: Unarmed while ignoring WF/EWF, or is that just dragon form? iv) How does Weapon Finesse work when in wildshape/ elemental form, or is it unnecessary?

There will, I'm sure, be more later, but in the meantime, any advice is appreciated from the ever-helpful Guild.

Cheers

posts.author: TheSquid
posts.content:
Great idea! "How to build a druid" happens to be one of my favourite topic NWN. To your questions:
1. You take Spell Focus to increase the DC of spells of the chosen school that offer a save. Conjuration focus is good on Druids because their area control spells (Grease, Web, Stonehold, SoV) are improved by it (as well as Bombardment I guess). Evocation is also good, you improve the DC of Flame Strike and Fire Storm and Call Lightning and Sunburst and Earthquake and whatnot. Abjuration looks bad, as Druid has _zero_ spells of this school that care about saves. Another school to consider is Transmutation (Drown! Nature's Balance! Cool Druid-only spells!)
2. Druid shapes (except maybe Dragon, which you are not taking) have _really bad_ AC. If you want to fight shifted at all, I think you need a way to fix that, and there is mostly only one (assuming your WIS will be high) and that is dip into Monk. Assuming you don't want to do this, I suggest forgetting shapes and thinking of fighting in gnome form, kind of like a Cleric with much worse AB, better defenses, one more companion, and incapacitated enemies. So yes you can take the usual melee feats if you so desire.
3. Weapon Finesse works when shifted, as do IC, as does Epic Prowess, and WF/EWF do not work. But you probably should not plan on shifting.

I am happy to discuss further, as I said I like the topic very much.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Keep in mind that Druids have Animal Empathy as a skill, and depending on the environment, this is an excellent investment.  Druids are called a "one person army" for a reason : Summons, Animal Companion, Animal Empathy, plus Druid makes 4 (a complete party!).

Grab yourself an extra meatshield (and it is great for grabbing summons from enemies as well).

Druids are known as the ultimate disablers - they have spells (nice AoE) that attack all three Saves (Reflex, Fort, and Will), so you can always exploit the "weak" saves of your opponents - Grease for Reflex, Stonehold for Will, SoV for Reflex, Finger of Death for Fort, etc.

Even though some of the shapes are kind of weak, most of the elemental shapes are good choices (immunity to mind, immunity to crits, immunity to sneaks, etc), especially when you have laid down some nice AoE disabling spells and need to go into action.  It's something to keep in mind.  Epic Elemental Shape can be pretty niffty at lower epic levels.

I have many druid builds on WoG, some are dragons, others are not.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
No, Druids do not have to choose Domains, it is "baked in" i.e. Animal Domain.

Which is how one can get three Domains in one PC (Cleric with a level of Druid, for example).

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I am pleased to see you thinking of making a caster Druid. As often before, your inspiration comes from reading.
Any serious caster should have a high number of class levels to beat SR. I'm not necessary saying "go pure Druid" here. You have already decided not to.
Monk has a high AC synergy with druid as long as you go in robes or naked or in shifted forms. Monk is also a good stepping stone to qualify for SD.
You already mentioned SD and HIPS for role-playing shyness. HIPS is great for crowd control too, just mentioning. You can also get HIPS with Kobold commando, but that takes you way into shifter land, and you cannot cast your spells while in shifted form.
You started thinking about Champion of BW. CoT (or any other deity) let you take Great wisdom as bonus feats in epic levels and improves your saves. But even so, please, pretty, pretty please, ... Don't make this another Divine warrior, that would be a complete derailment of your original idea.

Being honest, my inspiration here comes from my mother, whose 88th birthday would be tomorrow. She was only a little person (under 5ft, or 150cm), and I began - with my burgeoning irreverence - calling her a gnome from being about 14 (plus she had great crafting skills - head of art and design for over 40 years as a teacher). She was also passionate about nature - flora and fauna - so when I say 'she wouldn't hurt a fly', she really wouldn't. She reserved her hatred for those who wantonly destroyed the environment (when she looked like a vexed baby eagle). So I was looking to make a tribute build.

There, that's the soppy bit out of the way.

Now then, to the construction. If I was going for a human or half-elf, Monk would have been a no-brainer. But I'm not, because as a module player I don't want the xp hit (wouldn't even work with Hin). By the same token, when thinking of a third class, Ranger appealed, but same problem. Hence the CoT consideration. At the moment I'm contemplating either a D32/ CoT 6/ SD2 or a D36/ CoT 2/ SD2, so please don't lose sleep about the gnome of hittiness!
